title: Like Times. Just better.
author: popovich

comments.content:
Check out Storm Type's Lido, which was originally designed to replace Times in a Czech(?) publication.

Commercial license here:  
 [http://www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/families-73-lido-stf-comme...](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013185731/http:/www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/families-73-lido-stf-commercial-licence "http://www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/families-73-lido-stf-commercial-licence")

Development story here:  
 [http://www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/families-27-lido-stf](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013185731/http:/www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/families-27-lido-stf "http://www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/families-27-lido-stf")
Minion from Adobe makes a lovely Times replacement.

Not sure if it qualifies as a slab for you, but [The Antiqua](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013185731/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/lucasfonts/theantiqua_basic/&sample_text=Nice%20G%20and%20Straight%208&sample_size=36) meets your other requirements.

UltraFabulous, Minion is good, but I don't want to get into modifying the font (T has complex serifs, as I see it).

The Antiqua is very nice! Thank you, Stephen.

I was also looking into Candida and High Tower, which I like the most - except that serifs details will be lost completely, when engraved in small sizes. Hmm..

Here, I will show you what the point of the discussion is (see the image).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013185731im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ho8_check_4698.gif)
I think Meridien is your best here. I'd consider aligning the "F EIGHT" with the 8's baseline so the spacing is better.

Do you think there should be "f" or "F"? I personally don't see any reasons - logical or artful - for using small f here.

Though I really like Meridien's geometry, I am not sure about the serifs. Look:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013185731im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ho8_engr_check_3422.jpg)

The metal part is about 1/2 inch wide. I mean, at these sizes it is not really important to try to save the serifs. You just might get the picture of the applications of the logo...

Might I suggest Sumner Stone's 'Cycles'?

Not too expensive, very complete (optical sizes!).

[http://www.stonetypefoundry.com/html\_pages/CyclesOverview.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013185731/http:/www.stonetypefoundry.com/html_pages/CyclesOverview.html "http://www.stonetypefoundry.com/html\_pages/CyclesOverview.html")
